title: New AI classifier for indicating AI-written text

last_post.content:
OpenAI released a tool which purports to detect AI-generated text. At the highest end of detection, it labels text "possibly" or "likely" AI-generated. 21% of human-written text falls under "possibly" and 9% of "likely" does. That's 3 in 10 students being defamed and/or harmed.

Just like other providers of academic surveillance software, OpenAI states that their detector "should not be used as a primary decision-making tool".

It will be, though. And harm will follow.

https://openai.com/blog/new-ai-classifier-for-indicating-ai-written-text/

Catastrophic (and to be frank - hugely depressing)

This new research in @PNASNews suggests earth will cross the 1.5 degrees C temperature increase threshold in the next decade (within just 10 to 15 years) and is likely to exceed 2 degrees C by around 2060.

This should be THE lead story on the news today (and onwards) and the lead action point for our governments. It should trigger a massive call for real global action to combat the #climateemergency - sadly though I fear this news will barely register.

We have to stop believing the siren calls of future technology solutions and #carbonoffsets - the immediate need is a rapid end to the use of #fossilfuels and a massive rollout of #renewableenergy

https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.2207183120

#ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis

title: 10 Factors That Shape a Rumor’s Capacity for Online Virality — Election Integrity Partnership

last_post.content:
This fall, our team put out a "threat framework" for evaluating whether a specific rumors was likely to go viral or an event was likely to catalyze viral rumors. https://www.eipartnership.net/blog/rumors-capacity-online-virality-factors

One dimension of our framework is the "participatory potential" of a rumor — i.e. can people contribute, e.g. by adding new "evidence" or interpretations? In the "election fraud" rumoring space, this can look like sharing a photo or a personal experience of voting issues (real or perceived).

Here's a fun mystery to ponder on a Monday evening... the GitHub robots.txt file at https://github.com/robots.txt includes the following rules:

```
Disallow: /ekansa/Open-Context-Data
Disallow: /ekansa/opencontext-*
```
https://github.com/ekansa/Open-Context-Data is the ONLY repository on the whole of GitHub that gets explicitly listed in robots.txt like that

There's clearly a story there! I wonder what it is

Today I got a surprising and disheartening email from Wes of #Oakland & #Berkeley based Pitch Interactive notifying their contacts that they will be shutting their doors after 16+ years.

Pitch is *the* reason I became interested in #dataviz, after seeing their powerful piece on U.S. drone strikes titled, “Out of Sight, Out of Mind”: https://drones.pitchinteractive.com/

If you’re not familiar with Pitch and their work take a minute to check out their website: https://www.pitchinteractive.com/

Sad to hear @pitchinc@twitter.com is winding down —
thank you for 16+ years of #dataviz inspiration!

Check out their site if you haven't: https://www.pitchinteractive.com.

Absolute #dataviz classic: https://www.pitchinteractive.com/work/drones/

Best wishes for everybody on the team — you can truly be proud.

title: watershed moment for the BJD: Authors retain their article copyright

last_post.content:
The British Journal of Dermatology just moved from #Wiley to #OUP. As part of the move, it's adding plain language summaries (#PLS) and allowing authors to retain #copyright in their articles.
https://academic.oup.com/bjd/article/188/1/1/6795460

The journal remains #hybrid, not full #openaccess. But note that the key #RightsRetention step was voluntarily adopted by a #society (British Association of Dermatologists) and a #UniversityPress. Kudos to them both.

#nonprofit

title: Was this Brazilian major app bypassing Apple's location privacy on iOS? · Notes

last_post.content:
If you configured your iPhone to never allow an app to access your location, you may have been tracked anyway. Release notes for iOS 16.3 make mention of CVE-2023-23503, which Apple says may allow an app to bypass your privacy settings.

A blogger reports that an app from a Brazilian company iFood was able to track users' location even when they restricted the app's access. I haven't confirmed the report, but the screenshot seems convincing.

I wonder how long this vulnerability was in effect. There may have been massive amounts of location data that was collected without users suspecting a thing.

I'd ask Apple for details, but the company would never answer.

https://notes.ghed.in/posts/2023/ifood-bypassing-ios-privacy-location/

title: Open Sourcing SimCity, by Chaim Gingold - Don Hopkins - Medium

last_post.content:
although now long forgotten as a historical curio of 2000s web idealism, the OLPC "One Laptop Per Child" project attempted to produce a low-cost, high-reliability laptop suitable for kids in low-income environments.

one of the upshots of the program was that SimCity was open-sourced for the OLPC XO-1 computer, and it was included on every machine. this little article by don hopkins does a great job of tracing its history through Sun Microsystems.

https://donhopkins.medium.com/open-sourcing-simcity-58470a275446

#gamedesign #gamedev #RetroGaming #history

title: Langston Hughes reads The Negro Speaks of Rivers

last_post.content:
Today was my first time hearing Langston Hughes' voice. I'm glad I had the chance to listen to him reading one of his famous poems, which is apt for the first day of Black History Month in the United States, & since he was born on this day in 1901.

"I've known rivers:
I've known rivers ancient as the world and older than the
flow of human blood in human veins."

title: Netlify Acquires Gatsby Inc. to Accelerate Adoption of Composable Web Architectures

last_post.content:
I took a peep over at twitter to see what people there were saying about this news:

https://www.netlify.com/press/netlify-acquires-gatsby-inc-to-accelerate-adoption-of-composable-web-architectures/

A big misconception I'm seeing is that Netlify wanted to *own* a react-based framework and join that club, leading to lock-in.

The opposite is true. Netlify already support other open-source frameworks without lock-in or roadmap ownership. Expect that.

And Gatsby is wayyyy bigger than Gatsby.js. ☁️

I love this new version of @vincentab ‘s {marginaleffects}! The whole workflow has been streamlined so you can get predictions with predictions(), contrasts/comparisons with comparisons(), and partial derivatives with slopes() + single values with avg_*() + plots with plot_*()! #rstats #statsodon

title: Specialized Faculty Positions (Open Rank) - School of Information Sciences

last_post.content: The School of Information Sciences at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign is seeking to hire up to three full-time teaching faculty in fields that include data science, software development, database design, and library science. For candidates with a doctoral degree the teaching load is 2/2. Please boost if ppl in your network might be interested! #job https://illinois.csod.com/ux/ats/careersite/1/home/requisition/2993

title: Announcing ROR institutional identifier support for all Scholastica products

last_post.content:
Very glad to see this from #Scholastica.
https://blog.scholasticahq.com/post/ror-institutional-identifier-support/

"Including persistent identifiers (aka #PIDs) in article-level #metadata is one of the best ways to improve journal archiving and discovery while promoting #interoperability across scholarly communication systems. That’s why Scholastica [has]…integrated our peer review system, production service, and #OA publishing platform with #ROR institutional identifiers."

Ik botste toevallig op deze #dataviz over het ruimtegebruik van de transportinfrastructuur in Vlaanderen in 2018 (links, https://omgeving.vlaanderen.be/sites/default/files/2021-10/Rura-infographics.pdf), die gewoon smeekte om een correcte geschaalde voorstelling (rechts), door #auto, #fiets en #trein-infrastructuur. Bij deze!

title: Unable to burn digital books, Orange Unified School District bans the whole virtual library | Boing Boing

last_post.content:
One thing I'll say for the wave of Republican book-banning that's going on right now -- it's certainly making books seem powerful and *significant*

Book-banning is of course a terrible way to have the public re-realize the catalytic effect a good book can have on its readers

Nonetheless, here we are: https://boingboing.net/2023/01/31/unable-to-burn-digital-books-orange-unified-school-district-bans-the-whole-virtual-library.html

A #zettelkasten or commonplace provides a catalytic surface to which ideas in the “solution of life” can more easily adhere to speed their reaction with ideas you’ve already seen and collected. Once combined via linking, further thinking and writing, they can be released as novel ideas for everyone to use.  

#catalysts #combinatorial-creativity #commonplace-books #statistical-mechanics #zettelkasten

title: Workplace serendipity, invention, and lessons from Prohibition 1920-1933

1/ Friendly quibble. Oxford says that rights retention is a "new funder-led initiative."
https://openaccess.ox.ac.uk/home-2/rights-retention/

But it's not new and not funder-led. Many funders now have rights-retention OA policies and that's wonderful. Universities can help their researchers comply with funder policies by adopting university-based rights-retention policies, and that's wonderful.

But many universities had rights-retention OA policies before the latest wave of funders.
https://cyber.harvard.edu/hoap/Additional_resources#Policies_of_the_kind_recommended_in_the_guide

Dwarf Fortress 1.0 was finally released on Steam in December after 30 years of beta development, with the brothers who build it surviving on donations.

They went from $16k of donations in December to $7.2 million in January revenue from Steam.

Just, wow.

http://www.bay12forums.com/smf/index.php?topic=181354.0

NEW: Democrats could soon take over the local govt in Maricopa County, home to the Phoenix metro area & 4 million of Arizona's 7 million residents.

So several GOP lawmakers want to gerrymander it into 4 new counties by packing Dems & Latino/Black voters into 1 of them to ensure GOP controls the other 3. Maricopa as it currently exists had flipped to Biden in 2020, but 3/5 of the county's residents would end up in new Trump-won counties under this proposal to split it up. https://www.dailykos.com/stories/2023/2/2/2150505/-Afraid-of-losing-Arizona-s-biggest-county-Republicans-want-to-gerrymander-it-into-four-new-counties

It's gonna be livestreamed! Come and watch me talk in an hour or so :)

title: The MIT Press announces new initiative to flip existing subscription-based journals to a diamond open access publishing model

last_post.content:
A terrific project. Kudos to @themitpress and the #ArcadiaFund.
https://mitpress.mit.edu/the-mit-press-announces-new-initiative-to-flip-existing-subscription-based-journals-to-a-diamond-open-access-publishing-model/

"MIT Press welcomes submissions for English-language journals in any field and from any part of the world. Intended for existing titles, shift+OPEN will cover the expenses of transitioning a journal to [a #diamond or no-APC] #openaccess model for a three-year term, provide the Press’s full suite of publishing services, and support the development of a sustainable funding model for the future."
